I don't see why this game is getting the hate that it is. I've played the previous Little Nightmares games (including the DLCs and Very Little Nightmares), read the comics, and have now finished this game's story. While Supermassive Games had some big shoes to fill in terms of my expectations, I'm still quite surprised at how well they emulated Tarsier Studios in terms of gameplay and design. I'll go ahead and breakdown my overall opinions on Little Nightmares 3, for what little they're worth.


[h2] Pros [/h2]
- Outstanding visuals: others have said it, but the devs nailed the look and feel of the world of Little Nightmares. From player character designs, to backgrounds, to monsters, everything looks as though it was taken straight from its predecessors' concept art.

- Varied environments: the Spiral has a more hodgepodge approach to its set dressing, especially compared to the previous games. Whereas the Maw and the Pale City were fairly homogeneous, taking place almost entirely within their respective enclosures, each area of the Spiral feels like a completely different part of the setting's world.

- Interesting gimmicks: whether you choose Low or Alone, there are a number of instances throughout the levels where the player(s) will have to use the specific tools at their disposal to solve puzzles and overcome obstacles.

- A pleasant story: I won't lie, I was entirely lost in terms of what anything meant in Little Nightmares 3, up until the right near the ending, where everything seemed to finally click. Aside from the story told in cutscene form, it is also told through the interactions our two main characters share. It's plain to see how much they care for one another, and emotions are portrayed very clearly despite lacking any real dialogue.

[h2] Cons [/h2]
- Inconsistent AI: The greatest hurdle preventing enjoyment of the game is easily how rough the partner AI can be. I played this game solo (and as such, I'm sure that this con does not apply in multiplayer; however, the lack of split-screen co-op is another point of contention), and so I relied greatly on the AI for the many puzzles that require both players. While there were certain points in the game where I was pleasantly amused by how smart the AI was, there were twice as many times where I'd be forced to return to a prior checkpoint because my AI companion didn't want to follow me through a hole in the wall, or refused to help tear down a plank of wood as an enemy bore down on us.

- Cost/Playtime ratio: As you can see by my played time, it only took me 4 hours to beat LN3. This includes running around when a puzzle solution wasn't readily apparent, multiple deaths while doing so, and restarting due to the aforementioned glitchy AI. Even counting Very Little Nightmares, it could be argued that this is the shortest entry of the series. I find it hard to justify a $40 purchase of this game to anyone other than a diehard Little Nightmares groupie.

- Unclear progression: the aforementioned con is particularly glaring if you consider that there are multiple spots in each chapter where the way to progress is just not apparent at all. Certain gaps and cracks can be difficult (or even impossible) to see thanks to poor camera placement, missed grabs lead you to believe that a particular object isn't interactive, and at times the AI will simply ignore any command you give it to shoot/smash something or give you a boost.


[h1] OVERALL SCORE: 3.5/5 [/h1]


tl;dr - get this game on a 25% or more sale, you're welcome

Finished the game last night, and just wanted to throw my two cents in, before work. I've played the first two, and I wasn't going to buy this until Christmas. But the influx of negative reviews is what really made me check this out. Especially from my terminally online brother. Surely it couldn't be [b] THAT [/b] bad, right? Needless to say, it wasn't!

I wouldn't bother leaving a review, if so many of the negative reviews weren't borderline baseless. It's not disengaging, and it isn't devoid of depth. Even though the first two present theirs better (in my opinion), the third game clearly has a story to follow. Half of the reviews I've seen are fans moping about the series being "ruined," and the studio change being a dramatic stake through its heart. That would make sense, if one, Halloween wasn't over. And two, the flaws they're so worked up about made a genuinely bad game. Which they didn't. 

Both the core gameplay and visual storytelling feel almost flawlessly identical to the previous entries. To the point that, if the change in studio wasn't public, I'd wager 90% of players wouldn't notice. And the designs of the enemies felt more original than they did uninspired, which was a welcome relief.

The reviews that provide actual criticism, like the recycling of previous puzzles and mechanics, are sadly few and far between. While I like the game, I also think there's more to uncover, both story and gameplay-wise. Hopefully, the DLC ties everything together.

Overall, this is nowhere near the [b] nightmare [/b] I was described. Could it have been better at launch, like the first two? Of course. But I had fun playing, especially with a friend. And I think I'll try to have even more fun piecing together the new lore! Maybe.

8/10

First of all, i played both LN 1 and 2, i was extremely excited for the third because i wanted to see what happens next with the story. Right off i can say that the atmosphere is THERE, the proper atmosphere of the Little Nightmares franchise but a lot of the things seemed super reused, from mechanics to the music, to a bunch of other things, which is normal since the developers are not the same and i suppose they were trying to make the game as similar as the first and second one.

Although there is nothing wrong with the artstyle, atmosphere and colors, they could have done a better job with the lighting since in some levels its almost impossible to see certain vents and holes you're supposed to reach, especially when you're being chased by the boss.

THE CONTROLS.. the controls were super annoying at times and often didn't work, there are tons and lots of bugs... a LOT of bugs.

THE STORY... this is a little bit hard to judge from a one person perspective but i must say for the majority of the game, i felt like i was running into nothing and nowhere, without much meaning or explanation. The beauty about LN 1 and 2 was that they not only explained the story of the character but they also explained the reality and the way our world is going in extremely creative ways, where as the LN 3 went for a more psychological way rather than explaining why things are the way they are or why they happened.
I was expecting a continuation of Six' story and to understand what really happened, but i must say i was quite surprised to see the devs choosing completely new characters with their own stories. The big reveal and the ending was pretty interesting and cool but i kinda wish there was MORE to it, the game already did the big reveal quite early into the game and so afterwards you kinda already knew what was going to happen... in a way? Overall, i don't want to be negative about the game, it is still super fun to play in coop, not sure for singleplayer, the mechanics seem kinda pretty boring and super reused, only one mechanic i really really liked was the gift of the second sight.

Overall, i like the design of the characters, monsters, artstyle and the atmosphere, but it feels super reused. They should have went for something new mechanic wise like what i mentioned, but overall, its a game anyone should try. Is it worth 40 euros though? ABSOLUTELY NOT! It really does feel like a scam on that part.. and seeing as how you need to pay an extra 15 euro for the upcoming chapters.. yeah no.

I put it as recommended because i believe anyone should try the game, no matter the negatives, there could still be some beauty and fun in it. But i highly recommend that you try it in coop, its better that way, but it will never be nowhere near as fun and rewarding as LN 1 and 2.

Look it doesn't reach the heights of LN 1 or 2 but the fact that LN 3 comes close in any capacity to touching the first two games atmosphere is nothing short of remarkable.  These games aren't about thrilling gameplay (except for the chases of course) or hyper-complex puzzles.  It's always just about sitting back and soaking up the beautiful horror, which is something that LN 3 does better than I honestly thought it could.  

There is a running need in the reviews section here to directly compare Tarsier's Little Nightmare games to Supermassive's, which are of course unavoidable.  But context is everything, so to that end it's important to remember that Tarsier's parent company told them to start working on new IP and drop the LN series.  They had no say on the matter as they were freshly bought out, so they went along with it and now we'll be lucky enough to play ReAnimal in February as a result.  This is a great thing.  

But this also leaves a sizeable problem as to who could even attempt to continue this series after the first two amazing entries, and Supermassive stepped up and delivered.  LN 3 doesn't reach the level of raw menace that the first two games conjured on their own but it still nails the series' unsettling nature.  The graphics are stunning and while a few plot elements went directly over my head [spoiler] Killer plants at the Institute?  Wat? [/spoiler] , the mood was something that can really only come from the LN series.  

I did not experience a single bug but played the whole thing solo, in case that made a difference.  The co op angle is neatly explained by the plot and I never resented the game for forcing it, and the companion AI always did what needed to be done so there was truly nothing to complain about.  I missed the lonely nature of LN 1+2 but the co op was a nice angle of comparison, even though it was of course only jammed in there to get a few extra bucks for Daddy Bandai.  

39.99 seems a little stiff for the total run time, even though I felt every minute was high quality on its own.  I think this game would have a lot less negative reviews if the price point was 29.99 instead.  

I'm glad this game exists and really feels like LN, since I was never sure if anyone other than Tarsier could really sell it but Supermassive did a terrific job.

In my opinion, Little Nightmares 3 does not deserve as much negativity as it has been getting. (I should say that I am not a hardcore fan of the series, though I do find it very appealing.)

In my view, the game also managed to preserve its signature visual style (although I have read that many players did not like the level design or the bosses, I can only partially agree with that criticism).
I have also seen people mention that the game is buggy. I personally did not encounter a single bug during my playthrough, but of course that is a subjective experience. I assume the bugs do exist, but I can only judge based on what I have seen myself.
However, I think the negativity comes from a combination of factors, including:
Supermassive Games currently has a mixed reputation after the uneven The Dark Pictures series, which led to skepticism even before Little Nightmares 3 was released.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3584204356
The gameâ€™s price went up. It started as an indie project, but as the brand grew, the publishers raised the price accordingly. Unfortunately, aside from the co-op element, the game did not manage to offer much more (some even say it made certain aspects worse than in previous entries) and certainly did not surprise players.
There is also Reanimal, a similar game made by former developers of the series, whose demo was released around the same time. Many people liked it more, making comparisons inevitable.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3585606447
In the end, Little Nightmares 3 is a decent co-op experience with the seriesâ€™ recognizable style. However, beyond the co-op addition, it fundamentally fails to bring anything truly new or exciting. It is not a bad game by any means, but fan expectations played a cruel trick on it, and I think it will inevitably go down as a failure in the eyes of many.

I really wish Steam had an option somewhere in the middle when it comes to reviewing, because I canâ€™t say that this is a bad game on its own. It was a solid attempt. But as a Little Nightmares sequel, and with the way Bandai was hyping it up? Boy, was it a mess. Buckle up, because this will be a longer one.

When LN2 came out, it was a step up from the first game in every possible aspect: the story, the enemies, the locations, the overall scale. This one, however, feels more like a botched DLC than anything else. It seems like Supermassive was trying to recreate LN2 instead of moving the series forward or elevating it in any meaningful way. But, as they say, you really canâ€™t catch lightning in a bottle twice. The game relies on reused assets, reused rooms, reused shots, and reused puzzles. Itâ€™s a copy even down to the issues I had with the previous entry. Like what do you mean you can still fall off the platform due to bad perspective? And donâ€™t even get me started on the character AI..
Even though they managed to imitate Tarsierâ€™s distinct style, the game still lacks everything that made Little Nightmares great. First of all, itâ€™s unfortunately not scary at all. The sense of dread and anxiety that gripped you in the previous installments? Gone completely. Even the chase scenes couldnâ€™t salvage it (the baby is goofy af, Iâ€™m sorry). The only section that came somewhat close to the original atmosphere was in the final location. That should have been the whole game! Second, the gameplay and puzzlesâ€¦ boring, unimaginative, and unchallenging. The number of times you have to press a button or fetch the fricking fuses again (always the fuses) to proceed is way too high. I understand that Supermassive was trying to play it safe, and I also understand that living up to Tarsierâ€™s legacy is near impossible, so all of this I was willing to overlook. But the story? That was, I think, the biggest disappointment for me. It feels like a non-cohesive patchwork of locations glued together without any overarching goal, and the visual storytelling that was essential to the series? Non-existent. This is especially unfortunate if your only other source of narrative explanation is a podcast that most players probably havenâ€™t listened to. Which brings me to my next point, what was Bandai thinking? The last thing anyone wants is for this to turn into the Little Nightmares Cinematic Universe. Cross-referencing your other media can be fun and even welcome, AS EASTER EGGS, but basing the entire ending on it and making casual players feel obliged to consume your other content just to understand the plot is a very poor strategy from Bandai.

Now, just so this review isnâ€™t all negative: I genuinely enjoyed Low and Alone. Even if their relationship was nowhere near as satisfying as watching Six and Mono grow closer over the span of LN2. I even thought the twist at the end was pretty good, but everything else was justâ€¦ not it. Half the game is spent walking to the right without any purpose or anything interesting going on, while spooky sounds play and bland and uninspired monsters roam about in the background, while the other half is spent on really basic and straightforward gameplay that's only interesting when it's flat out copying scenarios from the first two games. Several times during my playthrough I was like "wait, they did this in the first game" or "this exact hallway full of monsters that I have to sneak though was in the second game." It seems Supermassive can't design a compelling gameplay scenario, or even a competent one, if their lives depended on it. Too many visual artists and not enough game designers at the company it seems.

Low and Alone's story is sweet, and I genuinely love their character designs and unique abilities, but ultimately it goes nowhere with little mystery or tension. The allegorical core of Little Nightmares has always drawn from that well of fear that all children feel toward adulthood, the adult world, growing up, and change in general, but Supermassive seems to misunderstand this and instead makes this a tale about mental health and a fear of one's physicians, like a child scared of their doctor simply because they're an unfamiliar adult. Basic, boring, and downright insulting to the legitimate fears of youth.

Ultimately, this game just feels like it was an assignment from Bandai Namco to Supermassive and that no one involved really cared about the series beyond just making another entry to keep the franchise alive. SPOILERS BELOW:
Little Nightmares 3 overall is a fine game. The environments are probably its strongest feature as most of them look incredible. The Carnival and final chapter imo contain some of the best visuals in the entire franchise, which make the rest even more painful. The game has so much potential that it utterly wastes. 
First of all it has less chapters than the previous game. Sure, the chapters are slightly longer and have more variety between them, but I was expecting more. The Factory, which arguably could be the setting for a whole game on its own, felt absurdly short in contrast to all the marketing it recieved before release, same with the Necropolis. The Carnvial and Institute both were pleasant surprises by their lenght even though they did not have many interesting things to do. In any case, it was good to see the final chapter having more work put into it compared to the previous games.
Second, I'm stilll not sure about what this whole game is even about. Having listened to The Sounds of Nightmares, I have a general understanding of the story, but that's not really the point. Both previous games had a core message and theme that the whole setting was built around. LN1 had the Maw - a manifestation of hunger, greed and gluttony, it really delved deep into the disgusting reality of modern over-consumption and how it corrupts people. LN2 had the Signal Tower and the Pale City, both manifestations of escapism. I was not expecting the depression I felt when playing the Pale City chapter. Seeing this horrible, decayed world where people are so desperately miserable, they seek any form of escape, even if it kills them. It really left an impact on me. LN3 on the other hand just did not have that punch. It's missing this "anger at modern society" that you could feel in the writing of the previous games. Apparently the themes were "illusions and delusions", but those were explored on such a surface level. Even the final reveal at the ending was predictable and unoriginal, and did not add anything to the core message.
The Spiral as a place also fails to engage with the core themes. I played the game, and yet I still have no idea on what "the Spiral" is. When it was announced, in an interview it was said that it is "a cluster of dystopian lands". This to me had always felt as an excuse to have different spooky places without having to really connect them logically and thematically. Unfortunately, after playing the game, I feel like I haven't been proven wrong.
What probably baffles me the most is the inclusion of the mirrors. They seemed so important and central to the story in the beginning. Anyone who has been a fan of this franchise for some time would have imediatelly drawn the connection the the Mirror Man from the old comic series. Even the cover art, with a stack of smoke swirling out of a mirror implies the existance of this Resident. Maybe we will find out what was his connection the the Lady in the first game? Maybe Otto is the mirror man - a psychiatrist twisted by his own delusions, where he now gains sadistic joy from revealing the deepest flaws and insecurities in others? No. None of that. I wonder where the writing went wrong in the process, becuause it just feels like these things weren't considered at all, which is just confusing.
At the very least they could have revealed the most mysterious character of them all - the Ferryman - to the general public who does not engage with secondary media. But that characters seems to be left for comics and podcasts.
It hurts me to say this as a long-time fan of the franchise, but I just can't recommend anyone buying this game. Not for the price it has, nor the content. I'm hoping this isn't the end and there is a brighter future ahead. because there is fertile soil in this world, one just has to know how to cultivate it.

Please beware, this game is genuinely terrible. First of all its buggy, from glitches occurring requiring resets to checkpoints to an entire boss chase section just not working outright, leaving us running away from nothing and wondering if a chase was supposed to be there, and finding it out through a youtube vid. 

Also, despite the playtime, this game is really short, the reason the playtime is so long is because the game is so tedious that any chase segment becomes a matter of replaying it 50 times each cause my friend and I would die in the most nonsense ways. 

The best way to describe it is similar to what other reviews say. You'll have the right idea for how to navigate a chase, die to some nonsense or bug, rethink the idea and try other paths or strategies that are guaranteed wrong and will lead to many more deaths, only to go back to the original method and find out it was most likely a glitch that killed you and the initial strategy was correct. 

It becomes a game of trial and error and when you're running the same boss chase sequence for the 20th time it becomes boring and frustrating. 

Also a game that's essentially 4,5 hours max is crazy.

Lore-wise: The game should not be Little Nightmares III, instead it should be a loosely related non-canon game, or something. It's like they didn't understand the universe of the Little Nightmares from the previous games, & just added in things in vain to make it loosely tied in (the dolls, the grotesque people, the collectibles), it's like they don't understand why these villains were in the other games to begin with... the story was... meh.

The NPCs barely acknowledged our existence, I mean, compare the way they act in I & II, to this, the guests on the Maw are trying to eat you, a crowd of chase you through the hall dragging themselves desperately trying to grab you, or the teacher shoving her head through the vents to get you... but in III... it's not the same.

Gameplay-Wise: The entire experience was run, climb, crouch, no real boss battle, no real "oh crap!" moments, just... run down this hall & jump. Meh. The Kin level was cool, but other than that... nah, it definitely failed. Even the circus was just duck & walk slow, climb & crouch. I'm disappointed. On top of that... the game is glitchy, my character sometimes looks like she's riding an invisible bike, the grab mechanics were iffy, especially on the hot air balloon part. 

On the plus, you can get a friend pass. 

All in all... 4/10.
